translated: The Elder Nuns’ Verses
The Chapter with Khattiyas
The Elder Nun Uppaladāyikā’s Verses
In the city of Aruṇavatī,
there was a Khattiya called Aruṇa.
I was the wife of that king,
and we lived together.
When I was sitting in private,
I thought like this at that time:
‘I have not done anything good,
and I will have to go taking that with me.
A great affliction, bitter,
horrible, very terrible,
I will surely go to hell,

analyzed: ettha me na atthi sa sayo
translated: I have no doubt about this.’
Having thought like this,
and having calmed my mind,
I approached the king 🔽and spoke this statement:
‘Your Majesty, we women
are inferior to men.
Give me a monk,
so that I can feed him, Khattiya.’
The king gave me then
a monk with developed faculties.
Taking his bowl,
I filled it with the finest food.
Having filled it with the finest food,
together with fragrant ointments,
covered with a large robe,
I gave it with a joyful mind.
By that deed well done,
And by my intention and resolution,
Having left behind my human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
I made great merit for a thousand celestial kings,🔽I made great merit for a thousand world-rulers.
A vast kingdom, beyond counting,

analyzed: padesarajjam vipula  gaṇanātaḥ a saṅkhiya  nānāvidham bahum
translated: And many other various things,
Are the fruit of that deed.
My complexion is like a blue lotus,
I am beautiful and good to look at,
I am endowed with all the parts of a woman,
I am of noble birth, a radiant one.
In my last existence,
I was born in the Sākya clan;
I was the foremost of a thousand women,
I was the daughter of King Suddhodana.
Disenchanted with the home life,
I went forth into homelessness;

analyzed: sattamī ratti sampattā  catur a cam a pāpuṇi
translated: On the seventh night of my going forth,🔽I attained the four noble truths.
The robe, alms-food,
and the requisites of a monk,
I am unable to fully enjoy,
this is the fruit of the alms-food.
The wholesome deed that I have fulfilled,
O Sage, you know well;
For your sake, O Great Hero,
I have served you much.
In the past, twenty-one eons ago,
the gift I gave then
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of that alms-giving.
I know two destinations,
the divine and the human;
I do not know of any other destination,
this is the fruit of that alms-giving.
I know a high family,
greatly wealthy and prosperous;
I do not know of any other family,
this is the fruit of that alms-giving.
Having transmigrated through existence and non-existence,
urged on by the root of merit,
I do not see anything unpleasant,
the fruit of the mind being joyful.
I have mastery over the spiritual powers,
and the divine ear element;
I have mastery over the knowledge of others' minds,
great sage.
I know my past lives,
the divine eye is purified;
All the pollutants are destroyed,
there is no more renewed existence.
In the meaning, the Dhamma, the phrasing,
and in eloquence, likewise;
Knowledge has arisen in me, great hero,
in your presence.
My defilements are burned up,
I dwell without pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me,🔽...
I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.”
The four analytical knowledges,
I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ uppaladāyikā bhikkhunī bhagavato sammukhā imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam uppaladāyikā bhikkhunī bhagavataḥ sammukhāḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus the nun Uppalavaṇṇā recited these verses in the presence of the Buddha.
The Story of the Elder Nun Uppalavaṇṇā is the third.
